maml:description.maml:para: Gets SQL Database capabilities for the current subscription.

The Get-AzureRmSqlCapability cmdlet gets the Azure SQL Database capabilities available on the current subscription for a region. If you specify the ServerVersionName, EditionName, or ServiceObjectiveName parameters, this cmdlet returns the specified values and their predecessors.
Specifies the name of the Location for which this cmdlet gets capabilities. For more information, see Azure Regions (http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/regions/).
Indicates that this cmdlet gets only defaults.
Specifies the name of the Location for which this cmdlet gets capabilities. For more information, see Azure Regions (http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/regions/).
Specifies the name of the database edition for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.
Specifies the name of the server version for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.
Specifies the name of the service objective for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.
Indicates that this cmdlet gets only defaults.
Specifies the name of the database edition for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.
Specifies the name of the Location for which this cmdlet gets capabilities. For more information, see Azure Regions (http://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/regions/).
Specifies the name of the server version for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.
Specifies the name of the service objective for which this cmdlet gets capabilities.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get capabilities for the current subscription for a region
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlCapability -LocationName "Central US" Location : Central US Status : Available SupportedServerVersions : {12.0, 2.0}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the capabilities for SQL Databases on the current subscription for the Central US region.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get default capabilities for the current subscription for a region
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlCapability -LocationName "Central US" -Defaults Location : Central US Status : Available ExpandedDetails : Version: 2.0 (Default) -> Edition: Standard (Default) -> Service Objective: S0 (Default)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the default capabilities for SQL Databases on the current subscription in the Central US region.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get details for a service objective
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlCapability -LocationName "Central US" -ServiceObjectiveName "S1" Location : Central US Status : Available ExpandedDetails : Version: 12.0 (Available) -> Edition: Standard (Default) -> Service Objective: S1 (Available) Version: 2.0 (Default) -> Edition: Standard (Default) -> Service Objective: S1 (Available)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets default capabilities for SQL Databases for the specified service objective on the current subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the status of moving elastic databases.
The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseActivity cmdlet gets the status of elastic databases moving into or out of an elastic database pool in Azure SQL Database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the SQL Server that hosts the elastic database pool.
Specifies the ID of the operation that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets status.
Specifies the name of the elastic database pool for which this cmdlet gets status.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets status.
Specifies the name of the elastic database pool for which this cmdlet gets status.
Specifies the ID of the operation that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the SQL Server that hosts the elastic database pool.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get status for all SQL Database instances
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseActivity -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -ElasticPoolName "elasticPool01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the operation status of all SQL Database instances in an elastic pool named elasticPool01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the auditing policy of an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy cmdlet gets the auditing policy of an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server where the database is located.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server where the database is located.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the auditing policy of an Azure SQL database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" DatabaseName : database01 UseServerDefault : Disabled ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 StorageAccountName : StorageKeyType : Primary EventType : {PlainSQL_Success, PlainSQL_Failure, ParameterizedSQL_Success, ParameterizedSQL_Failure...} AuditState : New RetentionInDays : 0 TableIdentifier : Server01Database01

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the auditing policy of database database01 located in server01 in resource group resourcegroup01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the data masking policy for an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingPolicy cmdlet gets the data masking policy of an Azure SQL database. To use this cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the data masking policy from database database01 in resource group resourcegroup01 on server server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the data masking rules from an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule cmdlet gets either a specific data masking rule or all of the data masking rules for an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database, and the RuleId parameter to specify which rule this cmdlet returns. If you do not provide RuleId, then all the data masking rules for that Azure SQL database are returned.
Specifies the name of the resource group the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.
Specifies the name of a schema.
Specifies the name of an Azure SQL Table.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the resource group the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of a schema.
Specifies the name of the server.
Specifies the name of an Azure SQL Table.
None.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all data masking rules from a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all data masking rules from database01 in resource group resourcegroup01 found on server server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a database along with its expanded property values.
The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseExpanded cmdlet gets a database along with its expanded property values.

Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database to get.
Specifies the name of the database to get.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get database object with service tier advisor information

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a geo-redundant backup of a SQL database.
The Get-AzureRMSqlDatabaseGeoBackup cmdlet gets a specified geo-redundant backup of a SQL database or all available geo-redundant backups on a specified server.

A geo-redundant backup is a restorable resource using data files from a separate geographic location. You can use Geo-Restore to restore a geo-redundant backup in the event of a regional outage to recover your database to a new region.
Specifies the name of the resource group the SQL database server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the backup to restore.
Specifies the name of the database to get.
Specifies the name of the database to get.
Specifies the name of the resource group the SQL database server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the backup to restore.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all geo-redundant backups on a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRMSqlDatabaseGeoBackup -ResourceGroupName "ContosoResourceGroup" -ServerName "ContosoServer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all available geo-redundant backups on a specified server.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a specified geo-redundant backup
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRMSqlDatabaseGeoBackup -ResourceGroupName "ContosoResourceGroup" -ServerName "ContosoServer" â€“DatabaseName "ContosoDatabase"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the database geo-redundant backup named ContosoDatabase.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the geo-replication links between an Azure SQL Database and the specified Azure resource group or Azure SQL Server.

The Get-AzureRMSqlDatabaseReplicationLink cmdlet replaces the Get-AzureSqlDatabaseCopy cmdlet. It gets all geo-replication links between the specified Azure SQL Database and a resource group or Azure SQL Server.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group for the database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server for the database to retrieve links for.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group the partner is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group for the database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server for the database to retrieve links for.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server for the partner.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group the partner is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group the partner is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server for the partner.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group for the database for which to retrieve links.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server for the database to retrieve links for.
This cmdlet accepts instances of the ReplicationLink or the Database object for the primary or secondary database.
The output type is a ReplicationLink object.
This cmdlet retrieves the distinct restore points that an Azure SQL Data warehouse can be restored from.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseRestorePoints cmdlet retrieves the distinct restore points that an Azure SQL Data warehouse can be restored from. For an Azure SQL Database, the restore window is continuous, meaning that any point in time within the database's backup retention period can be used as a restore point.
Specifies the name of the resource group the Azure SQL Database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server hosting the database.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database.
Specifies the name of the resource group the Azure SQL Database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server hosting the database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get all restore points
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseRestorePoints -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 DatabaseName : database01 Location : Central US RestorePointType : CONTINUOUS RestorePointCreationDate : EarliestRestoreDate : 8/12/2015 12:00:00 AM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns all available restore points for the Azure SQL Database named database01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the secure connection policy for an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseSecureConnectionPolicy cmdlet gets the secure connection policy of an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database. After this cmdlet runs successfully, it returns an object describing the current secure connection policy as well as the database identifiers. Database identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of server that hosts the database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the secure connection policy of an Azure SQL database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseSecureConnectionPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" DatabaseName : database01 ConnectionStrings : Microsoft.Azure.Commands.Sql.SecureConnection.Model.ConnectionStrings ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 ProxyDnsName : server01.database.secure.windows.net ProxyPort : 1433 SecureConnectionState : Optional

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the secure connection policy of an Azure SQL database named database01 located on server server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the threat detection policy for a database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseThreatDetectionPolicy cmdlet gets the threat detection policy of an Azure SQL database. To use this cmdlet, specify the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database for which this cmdlet gets the policy.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of a server.
Specifies the name of a database.
Specifies the name of a database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of a server.
You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a Model.DatabaseThreatDetectionPolicyModel object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the threat detection policy for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseThreatDetectionPolicy -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup11" -ServerName "Server01" -DatabaseName "Database01" DatabaseName : Database01 ResourceGroupName : ResourceGroup11 ServerName : Server01 ThreatDetectionState : Disabled NotificationRecipientsEmails : EmailAdmins : False ExcludedDetectionTypes : {}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the threat detection policy for a database named Database01. The database is located on the server named Server01, which is assigned to the resource group ResourceGroup11.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the progress of a TDE scan of an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryptionActivity cmdlet gets the progress of a Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) scan of an Azure SQL database. If no encryption span is running, this cmdlet returns an empty list. For more information, see Transparent Data Encryption with Azure SQL Database (https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn948096) in the Microsoft Developer Network Library.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE encryption activity.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE encryption activity.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get TDE activity for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryptionActivity -ServerName "server01" -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -DatabaseName "database01" ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 DatabaseName : database01 Status : Encrypting PercentComplete : 3.662109

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the TDE activity for the database named database01 on the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the TDE state for an Azure SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryption cmdlet gets the state of Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) for an Azure SQL database. For more information, see Transparent Data Encryption with Azure SQL Database (https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn948096) in the Microsoft Developer Network Library. This cmdlet gets the current state of TDE, but both encryption and decryption can be long-running operations. To see the encryption scan progress, run the Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryptionActivity cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE status.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE status.
Specifies the name of the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE status.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database for which this cmdlet gets TDE status.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get TDE status for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryption -ServerName "server01" -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -DatabaseName "database01" ResourceGroupName ServerName DatabaseName State ----------------- ---------- ------------ ----- resourcegroup01 server01 database01 Disabled

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the status of TDE for the database named Database01 on the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets pricing tier hints for a SQL database.

The Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseUpgradeHint cmdlet gets pricing tier hints for upgrading an Azure SQL Database. Databases that are still in Web and Business pricing tiers get the hint to upgrade to the new Basic, Standard, or Premium pricing tiers.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database for which this cmdlet gets an upgrade hint.
Specifies the name of the SQL database for which this cmdlet gets an upgrade hint. If you do not specify a database, this cmdlet gets hints for all databases on the logical server.
Indicates whether databases in elastic database pools should be excluded from the returned recommendations.
Specifies the name of the SQL database for which this cmdlet gets an upgrade hint. If you do not specify a database, this cmdlet gets hints for all databases on the logical server.
Indicates whether databases in elastic database pools should be excluded from the returned recommendations.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database for which this cmdlet gets an upgrade hint.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get recommendations for all databases on a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseUpgradeHint -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns upgrade hints for all databases on the server named server01.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get recommendations for specific database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseUpgradeHint -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns upgrade hints for a specific database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get recommendation for all databases that are not in an elastic database pool
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseUpgradeHint -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -ExcludeElasticPoolCandidates $True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns upgrade hints for all databases that are not in an elastic database pool.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets elastic pool recommendations.
The Get-AzureRmSqlElasticPoolRecommendation cmdlet gets elastic pool recommendations for a server. These recommendations include the following values:

-- DatabaseCollection. Collection of database names that belong to the pool. -- DatabaseDtuMin. Data Transmission Unit (DTU) guarantee for databases in the elastic pool. -- DatabaseDtuMax. DTU cap for databases in the elastic pool. -- Dtu. DTU guarantee for the elastic pool. -- StorageMb. Storage in megabytes for the elastic pool. -- Edition. Edition for the elastic pool. Valid values are: Basic, Standard, and Premium. -- IncludeAllDatabases. Indicates whether to all databases in the elastic pool are returned. -- Name. Name of the elastic pool.
Specifies name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server for which this cmdlet gets recommendations.
Specifies name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server for which this cmdlet gets recommendations.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get recommendations for a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-AzureRmSqlElasticPoolRecommendation -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the elastic pool recommendations for the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets pricing tier hints for upgrading a SQL Database server.

The Get-AzureRmSqlServerUpgradeHint cmdlet gets pricing tier hints for upgrading an Azure SQL Database server. Hints may contain the elastic database pool and stand-alone database hints. Databases that are still in Web and Business pricing tiers get a hint to upgrade to the new Basic, Standard, or Premium pricing tiers, or to go into the elastic database pool. This cmdlet returns hints for all databases hosted on the specified server.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server for which this cmdlet gets an upgrade hint.

Creates a data masking rule for an Azure SQL database.

The New-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule cmdlet creates a data masking rule for an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, DatabaseName, and RuleId parameters to identify the rule. Provide the TableName and ColumnName to specify the target of the rule and the MaskingFunction parameter to define how the data is masked.
If MaskingFunction has a value of Number or Text, you can specify the NumberFrom and NumberTo parameters, for number masking, or the PrefixSize, ReplacementString, and SuffixSize for text masking.

If the command succeeds and the PassThru parameter is used, the cmdlet returns an object describing the data masking rule properties as well as the rule identifiers. Rule identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName, ServerName, DatabaseName, and RuleID.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database.

Specifies the lower bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the upper bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of characters in the beginning of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the number of characters in the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is an empty string.
Specifies the number of characters at the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.
Specifies the masking function that the rule uses. Valid values are:
-- Default -- NoMasking -- Text -- Number -- SocialSecurityNumber -- CreditCardNumber -- Email
The default value is Default.
Specifies the name of a schema.
Specifies the name of the database table containing the masked column.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.

The default value is Default.

Specifies the lower bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the upper bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of characters in the beginning of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the number of characters in the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is an empty string.

Specifies the name of the database table containing the masked column.
None.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -RuleId "rule01" -SchemaName "schema01" -TableName "table01" -ColumnName "column01" -MaskingFunction Number -NumberFrom 5 -NumberTo 14

The rule is a number masking rule that uses a random number between 5 and 14 as the mask value. The rule is named rule01.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an elastic database pool for an Azure SQL Database.
The New-AzureRmSqlElasticPool cmdlet creates an elastic database pool for an Azure SQL Database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the elastic pool will be assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that will host the elastic pool.
Specifies the maximum number of Database Throughput Units (DTUs) that any single database in the pool can consume. The default values for the different editions are as follows:
-- Basic. 5 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the minimum number of DTUs that the elastic pool guarantees to all the databases in the pool. The default value is zero (0).
Specifies the total number of shared DTUs for the elastic pool. The default values for the different editions are as follows:
-- Basic. 100 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the edition of the Azure SQL Database used for the elastic pool. Valid values are:
-- Premium -- Basic -- Standard
For the current preview, the edition must be Standard.
Specifies the storage limit, in megabytes, for the elastic pool. You cannot specify a value for this parameter for the Premium edition.
If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet calculates a value based on the value of the Dtu parameter. We recommend that you do not specify the StorageMB parameter.

If you specify StorageMB, but do not specify Dtu, the cmdlet calculates a value for Dtu. If you specify values for both, the values must be consistent. For more information about the relationship between storage and DTUs, see https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/sql-database-elastic-pool-reference/.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the elastic pool.
Specifies the name of the elastic pool that this cmdlet creates.
Specifies the maximum number of Database Throughput Units (DTUs) that any single database in the pool can consume. The default values for the different editions are as follows:
-- Basic. 5 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the minimum number of DTUs that the elastic pool guarantees to all the databases in the pool. The default value is zero (0).
Specifies the total number of shared DTUs for the elastic pool. The default values for the different editions are as follows:
-- Basic. 100 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the edition of the Azure SQL Database used for the elastic pool. Valid values are:
-- Premium -- Basic -- Standard
For the current preview, the edition must be Standard.
Specifies the name of the elastic pool that this cmdlet creates.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the elastic pool will be assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that will host the elastic pool.
Specifies the storage limit, in megabytes, for the elastic pool. You cannot specify a value for this parameter for the Premium edition.
If you do not specify this parameter, this cmdlet calculates a value based on the value of the Dtu parameter. We recommend that you do not specify the StorageMB parameter.

If you specify StorageMB, but do not specify Dtu, the cmdlet calculates a value for Dtu. If you specify values for both, the values must be consistent. For more information about the relationship between storage and DTUs, see https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/sql-database-elastic-pool-reference/.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the elastic pool.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create an elastic pool
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzureRmSqlElasticPool -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -ElasticPoolName "elasticpool01" -Edition "Standard" -Dtu 400 -DatabaseDtuMin 10 -DatabaseDtuMax 100 ResourceId : /subscriptions/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001/resourceGroups/resourcegroup01/providers/Microsoft.Sql/servers/server01/elasticPools/elasticpool01 ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 ElasticPoolName : elasticpool01 Location : Central US CreationDate : 8/26/2015 10:00:17 PM State : Ready Edition : Standard Dtu : 400 DatabaseDtuMax : 100 DatabaseDtuMin : 10 StorageMB : 409600 Tags :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an elastic pool in the Standard service tier named elasticpool01. The server named server01, assigned to an Azure resource group named resourcegroup01, hosts the elastic pool in. The command specifies DTU property values for the pool and the databases in the pool.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a communication link for elastic database transactions between two Azure SQL Database servers.

The New-AzureRmSqlServerCommunicationLink cmdlet creates a communication link for elastic database transactions between two logical servers in Azure SQL Database. Elastic database transactions can span databases in either of the paired servers. You can create more than one link on a server. Therefore, elastic database transactions can span across a larger number of servers.
Specifies the name of the resource group to which the server specified by the ServerName parameter belongs.
Specifies the name of the server on which this cmdlet sets up the communication link.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureRmSqlServerCommunicationLink -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup01" -ServerName "ContosoServer17" -LinkName "Link01" -PartnerServer "ContosoServer02"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a link named Link01 between ContosoServer17 and ContosoServer02.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the auditing of an Azure SQL database.

The Remove-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditing cmdlet removes the auditing of an Azure SQL database. To use this cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database. After you run this cmdlet, auditing of the database is not performed. If the command succeeds and you have used the PassThru parameter, the cmdlet returns an object describing the current auditing policy, as well as the database identifiers. Database identifiers include, but are not limited to, the ResourceGroupName, ServerName and DatabaseName.
If you remove auditing of an Azure SQL database, threat detection is also removed.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove the auditing of an Azure SQL database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditing -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the auditing of database named database01. That database is located on server01, which is assigned to the resource group named resourcegroup01.

maml:description.maml:para: Restores a SQL database.

The Restore-AzureRmSqlDatabase cmdlet restores a SQL database from a geo-redundant backup, a backup of a deleted database, or from a point in time in a live database. The restored database is created as a new database.
You can create an elastic SQL database by setting the ElasticPoolName parameter to an existing elastic pool.
Specifies the name of the resource group to assign the SQL database to.

Specifies the edition of the SQL database. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies the name of the elastic pool in which to put the SQL database.
Specifies the name of the service objective.
Specifies the deletion date as a DateTime object. To get a DateTime object, use the Get-Date cmdlet.
Indicates that this cmdlet restores a database from a backup of a deleted SQL database. You can use the Get-AzureRMSqlDeletedDatabaseBackup cmdlet to get the backup of a deleted SQL database.
Specifies the ID of the resource to restore.
Specifies the name of the SQL database server.
Specifies the name of the database to restore to.
Specifies the name of the resource group to assign the SQL database to.

Specifies the edition of the SQL database. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies the name of the elastic pool in which to put the SQL database.
Specifies the name of the service objective.
Indicates that this cmdlet restores a SQL database from a point-in-time backup.
Specifies the point in time, as a DateTime object, that you want to restore your SQL database to. To get a DateTime object, use the Get-Date cmdlet.
Use this parameter together with the FromPointInTimeBackup parameter.
Specifies the ID of the resource to restore.
Specifies the name of the SQL database server.
Specifies the name of the database to restore to.
Specifies the name of the resource group to assign the SQL database to.

Specifies the edition of the SQL database. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies the name of the elastic pool in which to put the SQL database.
Specifies the name of the service objective.

Specifies the ID of the resource to restore.

Indicates that this cmdlet restores a SQL database from a geo-redundant backup. You can use the Get-AzureRMSqlDatabaseGeoBackup cmdlet to get a geo-redundant backup.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Restore a database from a point in time
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Database = Get-AzureRmSqlDatabase -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" PS C:\> Restore-AzureRmSqlDatabase â€“FromPointInTimeBackup â€“PointInTime UTCDateTime -ResourceGroupName $Database.ResourceGroupName -ServerName $Database.ServerName -TargetDatabaseName "RestoredDatabase" â€“ResourceId $Database.ResourceID -Edition "Standard" -ServiceObjectiveName "S2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the SQL database named database01, and then stores it in the $Database variable.
The second command restores the database in $Database from the specified point-in-time backup to the database named RestoredDatabase.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Restore a database from a point in time to an elastic pool
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Database = Get-AzureRmSqlDatabase -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" PS C:\> Restore-AzureRmSqlDatabase â€“FromPointInTimeBackup â€“PointInTime UTCDateTime -ResourceGroupName $Database.ResourceGroupName -ServerName $Database.ServerName -TargetDatabaseName "RestoredDatabase" â€“ResourceId $Database.ResourceID â€“ElasticPoolName "elasticpool01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the SQL database named database01, and then stores it in the $Database variable.
The second command restores the database in $Database from the specified point-in-time backup to the SQL database named RestoredDatabase in the elastic pool named elasticpool01.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Restore a deleted database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$DeletedDatabase = Get-AzureRmSqlDeletedDatabaseBackup -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" PS C:\> Restore-AzureRmSqlDatabase â€“FromDeletedDatabaseBackup â€“DeletionDate $DeletedDatabase.DeletionDate -ResourceGroupName $DeletedDatabase.ResourceGroupName -ServerName $DeletedDatabase.ServerName -TargetDatabaseName "RestoredDatabase" â€“ResourceId $DeletedDatabase.ResourceID -Edition "Standard" -ServiceObjectiveName "S2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the backup for the deleted SQL database named database01, and then stores it in the $DeletedDatabase variable.
The second command restores the backup for $DeletedDatabase to the target SQL database named RestoredDatabase.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Geo-Restore a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$GeoBackup = Get-AzureRmSqlDatabaseGeoBackup -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" PS C:\> Restore-AzureRmSqlDatabase â€“FromGeoBackup -ResourceGroupName "TargetResourceGroup" -ServerName "TargetServer" -TargetDatabaseName "RestoredDatabase" â€“ResourceId $GeoBackup.ResourceID -Edition "Standard" -RequestedServiceObjectiveName "S2"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the geo-redundant backup for the database named database01, and then stores it in the $GeoBackup variable.
The second command restores the backup in $GeoBackup to the SQL database named RestoredDatabase.

maml:navigationLink.maml:linkText: Recover an Azure SQL Database from an outage

maml:description.maml:para: Resumes an Azure SQL Data Warehouse database.
The Resume-AzureRmSqlDatabase cmdlet resumes an Azure SQL Data Warehouse database.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database that this cmdlet resumes.
Specifies the name of the database that this cmdlet resumes.
Specifies the name of the database that this cmdlet resumes.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database that this cmdlet resumes.

maml:alert.maml:para: The Resume-AzureRmSqlDatabase cmdlet works only on Azure SQL Data Warehouse databases. This operation is not supported on Azure SQL Database Basic, Standard and Premium editions.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Resumes an Azure SQL Data Warehouse database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Resume-AzureRmSqlDatabase -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command resumes a suspended Azure SQL Data Warehouse database.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the auditing policy for an Azure SQL database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy cmdlet changes the auditing policy of an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database. Specify the StorageAccountName parameter to specify the storage account to be used for the audit logs and the StorageKeyType parameter to define the storage keys.

You can also define retention for the audit logs table by setting the value of the RetentionInDays and TableIdentifier parameters to define the period and the seed for the audit log table names. Specify the EventType parameter to define which event types to audit.

After the cmdlet runs successfully, auditing of the database is enabled. If the database used the policy of its server for auditing before you ran this cmdlet, auditing stops using that policy. If the cmdlet succeeds and you use the PassThru parameter, it returns an object describing the current auditing policy, as well as the database identifiers. Database identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the event types to audit. Valid values are:

-- PlainSQL_Success
-- PlainSQL_Failure
-- ParameterizedSQL_Success
-- ParameterizedSQL_Failure
-- StoredProcedure_Success
-- StoredProcedure_Failure
-- Login_Success
-- Login_Failure
-- TransactionManagement_Success
-- TransactionManagement_Failure
-- All
-- None

You can specify several event types. You can specify All to audit all of the event types or None to specify that no events will be audited. If you specify All or None at the same time, the cmdlet fails to run.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of retention days for the audit logs table. A value of zero (0) means that the table is not retained. The default value is zero. If you specify a value greater than zero, you must specify a value for the TableIdentifer parameter.

Specifies the name of the storage account to be used when auditing the database. Wildcards are not permitted. This parameter is not required. When this parameter is not provided, the cmdlet will use the storage account that was defined previously as part of the auditing policy of the database. If this is the first time a database auditing policy is defined and this parameter is not provided, the cmdlet will fail.
Specifies which of the storage access keys to use. Valid values are:

-- Primary
-- Secondary
The default value is Primary.
Specifies the name of the audit logs table. Specify this value if you specify a value greater than zero for the RetentionInDays parameter.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the event types to audit. Valid values are:

-- PlainSQL_Success
-- PlainSQL_Failure
-- ParameterizedSQL_Success
-- ParameterizedSQL_Failure
-- StoredProcedure_Success
-- StoredProcedure_Failure
-- Login_Success
-- Login_Failure
-- TransactionManagement_Success
-- TransactionManagement_Failure
-- All
-- None

You can specify several event types. You can specify All to audit all of the event types or None to specify that no events will be audited. If you specify All or None at the same time, the cmdlet fails to run.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.

Specifies the number of retention days for the audit logs table. A value of zero (0) means that the table is not retained. The default value is zero. If you specify a value greater than zero, you must specify a value for the TableIdentifer parameter.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.

Specifies the name of the storage account to be used when auditing the database. Wildcards are not permitted. This parameter is not required. When this parameter is not provided, the cmdlet will use the storage account that was defined previously as part of the auditing policy of the database. If this is the first time a database auditing policy is defined and this parameter is not provided, the cmdlet will fail.
Specifies which of the storage access keys to use. Valid values are:

-- Primary
-- Secondary
The default value is Primary.
Specifies the name of the audit logs table. Specify this value if you specify a value greater than zero for the RetentionInDays parameter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the auditing policy of a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -StorageAccountName "Storage31"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of database named database01 located on server01 to use the storage account named Storage31.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the storage account key of an existing auditing policy of a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -StorageAccountKey Secondary

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of database named database01 located on server01 to keep using the same storage account name but to now use the secondary key.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Set the auditing policy of a database to use a specific event type
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -EventType Login_Failure

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of database named database01 located on server01; the policy will log the Login_Failure event type. The command does not change the storage settings.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets data masking for an Azure SQL database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingPolicy cmdlet sets the data masking policy for an Azure SQL database. To use this cmdlet, use the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database. You can set the DataMaskingState parameter to specify whether data masking operations are enabled or disabled.

You can also set the PrivilegedLogins parameter to specify which users are allowed to see the unmasked data. If the cmdlet succeeds and the PassThru parameter is used, it returns an object describing the current data masking policy as well as the database identifiers. Database identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName, ServerName, and DatabaseName.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server hosting the database.
Specifies the name of the database where the policy will be set.

Specifies whether data masking operation is enabled or disabled. Valid values are:
-- Enabled -- Disabled
The default value is Enabled.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies which SQL users are excluded from masking.
This parameter is deprecated and will be removed from future releases.
Specifies a semicolon-separated list of privileged user IDs. These users are allowed to view the masking data.
Specifies the name of the database where the policy will be set.

Specifies whether data masking operation is enabled or disabled. Valid values are:
-- Enabled -- Disabled
The default value is Enabled.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies which SQL users are excluded from masking.
This parameter is deprecated and will be removed from future releases.
Specifies a semicolon-separated list of privileged user IDs. These users are allowed to view the masking data.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server hosting the database.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the data masking policy for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the data masking policy for a database named database01 on the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the properties of a data masking rule for an Azure SQL database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule cmdlet is used to set a data masking rule for an Azure SQL database. To use the cmdlet, provide the ResourceGroupName, ServerName, DatabaseName, and RuleId parameters to identify the rule. You can provide any of the parameters of SchemaName, TableName, and ColumnName to retarget the rule. Specify the MaskingFunction parameter to modify how the data is masked.

If you specify a value of Number or Text for MaskingFunction, you can specify the NumberFrom and NumberTo parameters for number masking or the PrefixSize, ReplacementString, and SuffixSize parameters for text masking. If the command succeeds, and if you specify the PassThru parameter, the cmdlet returns an object that describes the data masking rule properties and the rule identifiers. Rule identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName, ServerName, DatabaseName, and RuleId.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the masking function that the rule uses. Valid values are:

-- Default
-- NoMasking
-- Text
-- Number
-- SocialSecurityNumber
-- CreditCardNumber
-- Email
The default value is Default.

Specifies the lower bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the upper bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of characters at the beginning of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the number of characters at the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the number of characters at the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.
Specifies the name of a schema.
Specifies the name of the database table containing the masked column.
Specifies the name of the column targeted by the masking rule.
Specifies the name of the database.
Specifies the masking function that the rule uses. Valid values are:

-- Default
-- NoMasking
-- Text
-- Number
-- SocialSecurityNumber
-- CreditCardNumber
-- Email
The default value is Default.

Specifies the lower bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.

Specifies the upper bound number of the interval from which a random value is selected. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Number for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of characters at the beginning of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the number of characters at the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of a schema.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the number of characters at the end of the text that are not masked. Specify this parameter only if you specify a value of Text for the MaskingFunction parameter. The default value is 0.
Specifies the name of the database table containing the masked column.
None.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Change the range of a data masking rule in a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseDataMaskingRule -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -RuleId "Rule17" -NumberFrom 23 -NumberTo 42

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies a data masking rule that has the ID Rule17. That rule operates in the database named database01 on server server01. This command changes the boundaries for the interval in which a random number is generated as the masked value. The new range is between 23 and 42.

maml:description.maml:para: Switches a secondary Azure SQL Database to the primary in order to initiate failover.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseSecondary cmdlet is designed as a general configuration command, but is currently limited to initiating failover. Use it with the AllowDataLoss parameter to initiate a force failover during an outage. You do not have to this parameter it when performing a planned operation, such as DR drill. In the latter case the secondary databases will be synchronized with the primary before switching.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the Azure SQL Database Secondary is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server that hosts the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Indicates that this failover operation allows data loss.
Indicates that this operation is a failover.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the partner Azure SQL Database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the Azure SQL Database Secondary is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server that hosts the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the partner Azure SQL Database is assigned to.
Indicates that this failover operation allows data loss.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Indicates that this operation is a failover.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the partner Azure SQL Database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure resource group that the Azure SQL Database Secondary is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the Azure SQL Server that hosts the Azure SQL Database Secondary.
Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseSecondary accepts instances of the Database object for the secondary database to fail over and make the primary database.
The output type is a ReplicationLink object.
Sets a threat detection policy on a database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseThreatDetectionPolicy cmdlet sets a threat detection policy on an Azure SQL database. In order to enable threat detection on a database an auditing policy must be enabled on that database.
To use this cmdlet, specify the ResourceGroupName, ServerName and DatabaseName parameters to identify the database.
Specifies the name of the resource group the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server.
Specifies the name of the database where the policy will be set.
Specifies whether the threat detection policy contacts administrators by using email.

Specifies an array of detection types to exclude from the policy. Valid values are:
-- Sql_Injection -- Sql_Injection_Vulnerability -- Access_Anomaly -- Usage_Anomaly -- None
Specifies a semicolon-separated list of email addresses to which the policy sends alerts.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the database where the policy will be set.
Specifies whether the threat detection policy contacts administrators by using email.

Specifies an array of detection types to exclude from the policy. Valid values are:
-- Sql_Injection -- Sql_Injection_Vulnerability -- Access_Anomaly -- Usage_Anomaly -- None
Specifies a semicolon-separated list of email addresses to which the policy sends alerts.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the resource group the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server.
You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.
This cmdlet returns a Model.DatabaseThreatDetectionPolicyModel object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the threat detection policy for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseThreatDetectionPolicy -ResourceGroupName "ResourceGroup11" -ServerName "Server01" -DatabaseName "Database01" -NotificationRecipientsEmails "admin01@contoso.com;secadmin@contoso.com" -EmailAdmins $False -ExcludedDetectionType "Sql_Injection_Vulnerability", "SQL_Injection"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the threat detection policy for a database named Database01 on the server named Server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies TDE for an Azure SQL database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryption cmdlet modifies the Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) property of an Azure SQL database. For more information, see Transparent Data Encryption with Azure SQL Database (https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn948096) in the Microsoft Developer Network Library.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database that this cmdlet modifies.
Specifies the value of the TDE property. Valid values are:
-- Enabled -- Disabled
Specifies the name of the database that this cmdlet modifies.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the database is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the value of the TDE property. Valid values are:
-- Enabled -- Disabled

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Enable TDE for a database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseTransparentDataEncryption -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DatabaseName "database01" -State Enabled ResourceGroupName ServerName DatabaseName State ----------------- ---------- ------------ ----- resourcegroup01 server01 database01 Enabled

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables TDE for the database named database01 on the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties for an Azure SQL database, or moves an existing database into an elastic pool.

The Set-AzureRmSqlDatabase cmdlet sets properties for an Azure SQL database. In addition, you can specify the ElasticPoolName parameter to move a database into an elastic pool. If a database is already in an elastic pool, you can use the RequestedServiceObjectiveName parameter to assign a performance level.
Specifies the name of resource group the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies the name of the database.

Specifies the edition for the database. Valid values are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies name of the elastic pool in which to move the database.
Specifies the new maximum size for the database in bytes. You can specify either this parameter or MaxSizeGB. See the MaxSizeGB parameter for allowed values per edition.

Specifies the name of the service objective to assign to the database. For information about service objectives, see Azure SQL Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn741336.aspx) in the Microsoft Developer Library.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the new server.
Specifies the name of the database.

Specifies the edition for the database. Valid values are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies name of the elastic pool in which to move the database.
Specifies the new maximum size for the database in bytes. You can specify either this parameter or MaxSizeGB. See the MaxSizeGB parameter for allowed values per edition.

Specifies the name of the service objective to assign to the database. For information about service objectives, see Azure SQL Database Service Tiers and Performance Levels (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/azure/dn741336.aspx) in the Microsoft Developer Library.
Specifies the name of resource group the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the database.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the new server.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a database to a Standard S2 database
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabase -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -DatabaseName "database01" -ServerName "server01" -Edition "Standard" -RequestedServiceObjectiveName "S2" ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 DatabaseName : database01 Location : Central US DatabaseId : a1e6bd1a-735a-4d48-8b98-afead5ef1218 Edition : Standard CollationName : SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS CatalogCollation : MaxSizeBytes : 268435456000 Status : Online CreationDate : 7/3/2015 7:33:37 AM CurrentServiceObjectiveId : 455330e1-00cd-488b-b5fa-177c226f28b7 CurrentServiceObjectiveName : S2 RequestedServiceObjectiveId : 455330e1-00cd-488b-b5fa-177c226f28b7 RequestedServiceObjectiveName : ElasticPoolName : EarliestRestoreDate : Tags :

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add a database to an elastic pool
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlDatabase -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -DatabaseName "database01" -ServerName "server01" -ElasticPoolName "elasticpool01" ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 DatabaseName : database01 Location : Central US DatabaseId : a1e6bd1a-735a-4d48-8b98-afead5ef1218 Edition : Standard CollationName : SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS CatalogCollation : MaxSizeBytes : 268435456000 Status : Online CreationDate : 7/3/2015 7:33:37 AM CurrentServiceObjectiveId : d1737d22-a8ea-4de7-9bd0-33395d2a7419 CurrentServiceObjectiveName : ElasticPool RequestedServiceObjectiveId : d1737d22-a8ea-4de7-9bd0-33395d2a7419 RequestedServiceObjectiveName : ElasticPoolName : elasticpool01 EarliestRestoreDate : Tags :

dev:remarks.maml:para: The following command adds a database named database01 to the elastic pool named elasticpool01 hosted on the server named server01.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies properties of an elastic database pool in Azure SQL Database.

The Set-AzureRmSqlElasticPool cmdlet modifies properties for an elastic database pool in an Azure SQL Database. This cmdlet can modify the minimum Database Throughput Units (DTUs) per database, as well as the maximum DTUs per database, the number of DTUs for the pool, and the storage limit for the pool.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the elastic pool is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the elastic pool.
Specifies the name of the elastic pool.
Specifies the maximum number of DTUs that any single database in the pool can consume. The default values for different editions are:
-- Basic. 5 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the minimum number of DTUs that the elastic pool guarantees to all the databases in the pool. The default value is zero (0).
Specifies the total number of shared DTUs for the elastic pool. The default values for different editions are:
-- Basic. 100 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs

Specifies the edition of the Azure SQL Database for the elastic pool. You cannot change the edition. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies the storage limit, in megabytes, for the elastic pool. For more information, see the New-AzureRmSqlElasticPool cmdlet.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the elastic pool.
Specifies the maximum number of DTUs that any single database in the pool can consume. The default values for different editions are:
-- Basic. 5 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs
Specifies the minimum number of DTUs that the elastic pool guarantees to all the databases in the pool. The default value is zero (0).
Specifies the total number of shared DTUs for the elastic pool. The default values for different editions are:
-- Basic. 100 DTUs -- Standard. 100 DTUs -- Premium. 125 DTUs

Specifies the edition of the Azure SQL Database for the elastic pool. You cannot change the edition. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- None -- Premium -- Basic -- Standard -- DataWarehouse -- Free
Specifies the name of the elastic pool.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the elastic pool is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the server that hosts the elastic pool.
Specifies the storage limit, in megabytes, for the elastic pool. For more information, see the New-AzureRmSqlElasticPool cmdlet.
Specifies a dictionary of tags that this cmdlet associates with the elastic pool.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Modify properties for an elastic pool
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlDatabaseElasticPool -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -ElasticPoolName "elasticpool01" -Dtu 1000 -DatabaseDtuMax 100 -DatabaseDtuMin 20 ResourceId : /subscriptions/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001/resourceGroups/resourcegroup01/providers/Microsoft.Sql/servers/server01/elasticPools/elasticpool01 ResourceGroupName : resourcegroup01 ServerName : server01 ElasticPoolName : elasticpool01 Location : Central US CreationDate : 8/26/2015 10:00:17 PM State : Ready Edition : Standard Dtu : 200 DatabaseDtuMax : 100 DatabaseDtuMin : 20 StorageMB : 204800 Tags :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies properties for an elastic pool named elasticpool01. The command sets the number of DTUs for the elastic pool to 1000 and sets the minimum and maximum DTUs.

maml:description.maml:para: Provisions an Azure AD administrator for SQL Server.
The Set-AzureRmSqlServerActiveDirectoryAdministrator cmdlet provisions an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) administrator for Azure SQL Server in the current subscription.
Only one administrator can be provisioned at a time.
The following members of Azure AD can be provisioned as a SQL Server administrator:
-- Native members of Azure AD -- Federated members of Azure AD -- Imported members from other Azure ADs who are native or federated members -- Azure AD groups created as security groups

Microsoft accounts, such as those in the Outllook.com, Hotmail.com, or Live.com domains, are not supported as administrators. Other guest accounts, such as those in the Gmail.com or Yahoo.com domains, are not supported as administrators, either.
We recommend that you provision a dedicated Azure AD group as an administrator.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the SQL Server for which this cmdlet provisions an administrator.
Specifies the display name of the Azure AD administrator that this cmdlet provisions.
Specifies the unique ID of the Azure AD administrator that this cmdlet provisions. If the display name is not unique, you must specify a value for this parameter.
Specifies the display name of the Azure AD administrator that this cmdlet provisions.
Specifies the unique ID of the Azure AD administrator that this cmdlet provisions. If the display name is not unique, you must specify a value for this parameter.
Specifies the name of the resource group that the server is assigned to.
Specifies the name of the SQL Server for which this cmdlet provisions an administrator.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Provision an administrator group for a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlServerActiveDirectoryAdministrator -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DisplayName "DBAs" ResourceGroupName ServerName DisplayName ObjectId ----------------- ---------- ----------- -------- resourcegroup01 server01 DBAs 40b79501-b343-44ed-9ce7-da4c8cc7353b

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command provisions an Azure AD administrator group named DBAs for the server named server01. This server is associated with resource group resourcegroup01.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Provision an administrator user for a server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureRmSqlServerActiveDirectoryAdministrator -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DisplayName "David Chew" ResourceGroupName ServerName DisplayName ObjectId ----------------- ---------- ----------- -------- resourcegroup01 server01 David Chew 11E95548-B179-4FE1-9AF4-ACA49D13ABB9

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command provisions an Azure AD user (David Chew) as an administrator for the server named server01.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Provision an administrator group by specifying its ID
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlServerActiveDirectoryAdministrator -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -DisplayName "DBAs" -ObjectId "40b79501-b343-44ed-9ce7-da4c8cc7353b" ResourceGroupName ServerName DisplayName ObjectId ----------------- ---------- ----------- -------- resourcegroup01 server01 DBAs 40b79501-b343-44ed-9ce7-da4c8cc7353b

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command provisions an Azure AD administrator group named DBAs for the server named server01. The command specifies an ID for the ObjectId parameter. This ensures that the command will succeed even if the display name of the group is not unique.

maml:description.maml:para: Changes the auditing policy of an Azure SQL server.

The Set-AzureRmSqlServerAuditingPolicy cmdlet changes the auditing policy of an Azure SQL server. Specify the ResourceGroupName and ServerName parameters to identify the server, the StorageAccountName parameter to specify the storage account to be used for the audit logs, and the StorageKeyType parameter to define the storage keys to use.

You can also define retention for the audit logs table by setting the value of the RetentionInDays and TableIdentifier parameters to define the period and the seed for the audit log table names. Specify the EventType parameter to define which event types to audit. After you run this cmdlet, auditing of the databases that use the policy of this server is enabled. If the cmdlet succeeds and you specify the PassThru parameter, the cmdlet returns an object that describes the current auditing policy, and the server identifiers. Server identifiers include, but are not limited to, ResourceGroupName and ServerName.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the database.
Specifies the event types to audit. Valid values are:

-- PlainSQL_Success
-- PlainSQL_Failure
-- ParameterizedSQL_Success
-- ParameterizedSQL_Failure
-- StoredProcedure_Success
-- StoredProcedure_Failure
-- Login_Success
-- Login_Failure
-- TransactionManagement_Success
-- TransactionManagement_Failure
-- All
-- None

You can specify several event types. You can specify All to audit all of the event types or None to specify that no events will be audited. If you specify All or None at the same time, the command fails.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the number of retention days for the audit logs table. A value of zero (0) means that the table is not retained; this is the . If you specify a value greater than zero you must also specify a value for the TableIdentifer parameter.

Specifies the name of the storage account to be used when auditing the database. Wildcard characters are not permitted. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet uses the storage account that was defined previously as part of the auditing policy of the database. If this is the first time a database auditing policy is defined and you do not specify this parameter, the command fails.
Specifies which of the storage access keys to use. Valid values are:

-- Primary
-- Secondary
The default value is Primary.
Specifies the name of the audit logs table. Specify this value if you specify a value greater than zero for the RetentionInDays parameter.
Specifies the name of the server that contains the database.
Specifies the event types to audit. Valid values are:

-- PlainSQL_Success
-- PlainSQL_Failure
-- ParameterizedSQL_Success
-- ParameterizedSQL_Failure
-- StoredProcedure_Success
-- StoredProcedure_Failure
-- Login_Success
-- Login_Failure
-- TransactionManagement_Success
-- TransactionManagement_Failure
-- All
-- None

You can specify several event types. You can specify All to audit all of the event types or None to specify that no events will be audited. If you specify All or None at the same time, the command fails.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the name of the resource group that contains the database.

Specifies the number of retention days for the audit logs table. A value of zero (0) means that the table is not retained; this is the . If you specify a value greater than zero you must also specify a value for the TableIdentifer parameter.
Specifies the name of the server that contains the database.

Specifies the name of the storage account to be used when auditing the database. Wildcard characters are not permitted. If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet uses the storage account that was defined previously as part of the auditing policy of the database. If this is the first time a database auditing policy is defined and you do not specify this parameter, the command fails.
Specifies which of the storage access keys to use. Valid values are:

-- Primary
-- Secondary
The default value is Primary.
Specifies the name of the audit logs table. Specify this value if you specify a value greater than zero for the RetentionInDays parameter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the auditing policy of an Azure SQL server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlServerAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -StorageAccountName "Storage22"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of the server named server01 to use a storage account named Storage22.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the storage account key of an existing auditing policy of an Azure SQL server
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlServerAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -StorageAccountKey Secondary

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of the server named server01 to use the secondary key. The command does not modify the storage account name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Set the auditing policy of an Azure SQL server to use a specific event type
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureRmSqlServerAuditingPolicy -ResourceGroupName "resourcegroup01" -ServerName "server01" -EventType Login_Failure

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the auditing policy of the server named server01 to use the Login_Failure event type. This command does not modify any other setting.
